text: we are all I mean we are people who came
to work the factory where I was moved to
Santo Domingo me I really think it's
gonna get better
will it get to where it used to be it
never will globalization is here to stay
this is Nadia Sussman reporting for The
New York Times sewing machines still hum
in New York's garment Center 100 years
after a fire at the triangle factory
killed 146 workers there most were
immigrant women the 1911 tragedy sparked
Union drives and labor reforms that
transformed one of New York's largest
industries today in New York apparel
factories are far safer but far fewer
it's 8:30 in the morning in midtown
Manhattan a century after the triangle
fire new immigrants still look to
garment work as a way into the American
economy dozens of women line up on
eighth Avenue at 37th Street hoping for
a day's work
sewing ironing or snipping loose threads
from finished clothes many arrived as
early as 7:00 for a good spot in line by
11:00 the jobs are gone I'm waiting to
do cleaning or ironing or whatever work
there is to give a few days two days
three days a week but there's
practically no work for a whole week
Petric Quinto came to the u.s. 20 years
ago from Mexico after losing her job two
years ago she started to look for day
laborer Alec that's now the minimum wage
is $7.25 and in many places they want to
pay $6 an hour Petra is a permanent
resident but many day laborers in
Manhattan mostly from Ecuador and Mexico
are undocumented since they don't speak
any English people take advantage of
them say that for each other some
workers say they never get paid or are
told by employers that their work was
just a test
this woman was taking her time cards to
a factory to ask for her unpaid wages
two weeks of work that the Chinese lady
didn't pay me
Petra accompanying her to speak with the
factory owner she said I'll pay you on
Saturday come back Saturday and she took
the cards back several workers said this
was a common problem the State
Department of Labor which conduct
apparel factory inspections has
collected some twelve million dollars in
back wages for garment workers since
but here at down the dress one of the
few remaining union shops in Midtown
workers so designer gowns for
middle-class wages michael de palma runs
the 39th street factory with his father
Armand who founded the business 40 years
ago workers have been here in average of
10 to 15 years I have two people that
know me since I'm in high school they
used to call me the kid Dalma dress has
found a specialty that has kept them in
business as manufacturing has moved
abroad they have shifted to making
high-fashion dresses when this company
started out it was basically like a
popular price high volume but you have
to make adjustments and try and move on
everything here is high-end low-end
really is not in New York anymore the 30
or so employees that dhama dress are
among a few hundred union workers left
in the garment center which employs more
than 7,000 people overall membership in
garment union's peaked in the 1960s when
hundreds of thousands of people belonged
nationwide the recession has offered a
small unexpected boost to the De Palma's
business they have seen New York
designers who are looking to cut costs
opt to manufacture locally because it
allows them to maintain a lean inventory
and reorder at the last minute union
employees can make from 35,000 to
$100,000 a year plus benefits for highly
specialized work salaries that reflect
the gains of unions in the century since
the triangle fire
but the day laborers who wait in Midtown
lack an organization or advocates and
work has grown scarce some women have
turned to housecleaning in Brooklyn a
better paid alternative starting at $10
an hour loose Maria arias organizes
Latinas who do domestic day labor in
Williamsburg she moved to the u.s. from
Mexico in 1994 in order to work in the
garment industry and they said them at
that time I saw that there was a lot of
work in factories for me it meant
improving my economic situation I liked
it because it was something different
that we didn't have in our countries Luz
Maria sewed and ironed in a Queen's
apparel Factory for eight years until it
moved overseas while she scrubs floors
in the u.s. there are now garment
factories in her home state in Mexico
some immigrant garment workers have
returned to their home countries many
who remain struggled to survive it was
difficult to find undocumented day
laborers willing to talk on camera but
Petra wanted to speak for those who
couldn't so I'm speaking for my
companions for working people so that we
are respected because otherwise everyone
will do whatever they want to us and
we're people like everyone else
